Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Strong Disorder and Electron Interaction Effects in Topological Insulators
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The Division of Materials Research and the Division of Mathematical Sciences contribute funds to this CAREER award to support research on topological insulators, a new class of materials that have interesting and potentially useful edge and surface physics. The surface and edge states arise from topological properties of the quantum states inside the bulk of the material. As such, the properties of the edges and surfaces are expected to be robust against degradation, deformation or chemical contamination. They can, however, be destroyed by large, smooth deformations of the bulk structure or by strong disorder and electron interactions. The PI aims to quantify how much disorder a topological insulator can support without losing its definitive properties and to understand the effects of electron-electron interaction. The insight from traditional theoretical methods is limited when disorder and interactions are strong. The PI will develop new methods of analysis. Specifically, the PI will:

1) Use the methods of Non-Commutative Geometry to define robust topological invariants in the presence of strong disorder and electron-electron interaction, and to map out the precise conditions that assure their quantization and invariance,

2) Devise numerical algorithms to implement the non-commutative calculus and carry out explicit computer simulations to map out the phase diagram of various existing topological insulators in the presence of strong disorder, and

3) Using the results of 1 and 2, predict and characterize materials with novel topological properties.

The educational component of the proposal will contribute to the dissemination of modern problems in theoretical condensed matter physics and of the methods of modern mathematical analysis among a broad scientific community, through a series of planned, in-depth, and pedagogical reviews as well as colloquium-type publications. The PI will initiate the "Condensed Matter Blackboard Lectures", a forum to enhance communication and collaboration between condensed matter and mathematical physicists in the metropolitan New York City area. Furthermore, a series of activities and research scholarships are planned at the PI's institution, Stern College for Women of Yeshiva University, which will enhance the participation of the underrepresented minority students in science, in particular, in the field of theoretical condensed matter physics.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The Division of Materials Research and the Division of Mathematical Sciences contribute funds to this CAREER award to support research on a newly discovered state of matter called the topological insulating state. Materials exhibiting this state have highly unusual properties, e.g. while the bulk of the material is an electrical insulator, there are perfectly conducting charge and spin channels along any edge or surface that is cut into the bulk of the material. These edge or surface conducting channels are robust, that is, they do not vanish under moderate mechanical, chemical or heat stress. These materials may contribute to the foundations of future electronics, computer technology and clean energy generation, transportation and storage technologies.

The PI will focus on the characterization of topological insulators when imperfections proliferate to large numbers due to various factors such as the fabrication process, intense heat, radiation or mechanical stress. Since the structure of the material will no longer be perfectly ordered at the atomic level, but rather be randomly distorted, it is generally very difficult to characterize or make predictions about these materials with existing theoretical tools. To overcome this difficulty, the PI will employ a mathematical formalism called "non-commutative calculus", which is a generalization of the traditional calculus and geometry to cases when no underlying smooth space or geometrical object can be defined. This will enable a deeper understanding of the properties of topological insulators. The knowledge gained from these studies will guide experimentalists on how to improve the performance of existing topological insulators and aid in the search and discovery of new materials with exciting properties.

The educational component of the proposal will contribute to the dissemination of the modern problems in theoretical condensed matter physics and of the methods of modern mathematical analysis among a broad scientific community, through a series of planned, in-depth, and pedagogical reviews as well as colloquium-type publications. The PI will initiate the "Condensed Matter Blackboard Lectures", a forum to enhance communication and collaboration between condensed matter and mathematical physicists in the metropolitan New York City area. Furthermore, a series of activities and research scholarships are planned at the PI's institution, Stern College for Women of Yeshiva University, which will enhance the participation of the underrepresented minority students in science, in particular, in the field of theoretical condensed matter physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The prosperity of our society depends more and more on the advances in materials science. As always, such advances come in small steps via gradual improvement and tuning or by giant leaps which can be a result of a process of trial and error or of a theoretical prediction based on higher principles. The science of materials has witness such a leap with the discovery of topological insulators, which is an entirely new class of materials predicted theoretically on the principles of topology. The topology referred to here occurs not in the real space of the crystal but in the abstract space of the quantum states of the electrons. For periodic crystals, this space can be parametrize by the quasi-momentum of the electrons which is just a torus of appropriate dimension. As such, the space of the electron states in a perfect crystal can be no more complicated than a bundle of finite dimensional spaces glued together over this torus, very much like a cylinder or a Moebius band are. The two cases we mentioned, however, are topologically distinct because we all know that we cannot deform one into another without tearing apart the fabric. It is precisely this type of reasoning that led the condensed matter scientists to realize that the phases of matter can be finely organized in topological classes. Besides topology, an important ingredient is the intrinsic set of symmetries that are locked into place in a crystal, which can be time-reversal, particle-hole and chiral symmetries. Pioneering works in the second half of the 2000’s have predicted that there are distinct topological classes which possess the remarkable property of displaying boundary electron states whenever the crystal is cut in half. Furthermore, these boundary states were predicted to behave as perfect channels for the electron transport even in the presence of strong bulk disorder and surface imperfections. The technological implications of these predictions are enormous and they can change how we communicate, compute or design electronic components in the future.

One extreme difficulty for the field is dealing with the strong disorder because the classical picture of the torus painted above is no longer available. The research supported by this NSF award developed a theory of disordered crystals within the framework of Non-Commutative Geometry. In this theory, the classical Brillouin torus is replaced by a non-commutative algebra of physical observables, where a differential calculus is still available. As such, compact formulas can be derived for the physical response coefficients of a disordered crystal to external fields. Using such tools, our research showed that certain linear and non-linear response coefficients look formally similar to classical topological invariants. Furthermore, using guidance from the quantized calculus in Non-Commutative Geometry, we were able to formulate and prove a set of index theorems which remain stable in the regime of strong disorder. They provide a firm proof that the strong topological insulators are indeed distinct phases of matter, separated by sharp phase boundaries where an Anderson localization-delocalization quantum phase transition occurs. Furthermore, the same framework enabled us to develop extremely efficient and accurate numerical algorithms for mapping the phase diagrams of the topological crystals. They have enable many concrete applications and detailed studies of disordered topological insulators. Guided by previous applications of K-Theory, we were also able to formulate and prove the bulk-boundary principle for all topological phases classified by integer numbers. More precisely, we defined topological invariants for the boundary states of the electrons and showed that they are equal to the bulk invariants. Furthermore, we showed that it is precisely these boundary invariants that prevent the Anderson localization of the boundary states.

In the final stages of our research, we have turned the tools we developed into a machinary for serch and discovery of novel topological phases. Indeed, the methods apply well beyond the context of disordered crystals, for example, to incommensurate and frustrated systems, quasi-crystals and amorphous solids. Within these classes, our theory enables us to tell appart the systems with and without topological boundary spectrum and to predict many interesting topological systems. Many of these predictions have been already realized in laboratories using meta-materials.

The results of our research have been communicated in about thirty scientific publications and via about forty invited talks. One scientific publication gives a review of Kasparov's KK-Theory and showcases several applications in condensed matter physics. Furthermore, a fairly complete and coherent account of our research has been published in two textbooks, which were written in a very pedagogical style. During this award, the PI organized three local workshops, one summer school and an online course in K-theory.
